ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned how to adapt various statistical techniques to vastly different types of data.

I learned how to ask statistical questions relating to research from various fields (e.g. medical, biological, social, etc.). This class taught me how to work with experts from other fields and interact with their data.
I really enjoyed our weekly consulting meetings when we had a guest. It is interesting to be presented with new statistical problems and hear the differing ideas that students present.
How statistical methods can be applied to a wide range of topics - this course is more interesting than most.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Provides a great source of experience of working with real data for real world problems.
Strength: Exposure to many different fields of research. Weakness: More visitors from other fields should come (not just people from the Medical School - which was about 50% of the consultations).
It would be nice if there was more follow up on the individual presentations, for example continuing to work with a client after they have presented.
Could have smaller groups of students.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, at least as long as they understand the basics of statistics and R-programming.
Yes, of course! This class helps students ask their own questions to investigate the data and statistics behind other people's research.
Yes, the course is interesting and exposes you to statistics in a variety of contexts
Yes - not a bad way to spend Friday afternoon, gives some insight into the types of things statistics is applicable to.
